p: To better identify the initial focus of each outbreak, we adapted a previously developed method [ 6], where the most likely source location is identified as the location that maximizes the correlation between onset times and the geographic distance to the potential source (see methods). Notably, of the eight seasons studied, seven were likely seeded in the Southern US ( Fig 5 and supporting S1 Text, Figure A4). The relationship between influenza timing and distance to the source location was particularly pronounced in four seasons (2002/2003, 2003/2004, 2005/2006 seasons and the 2009 pandemic, supporting S1 Text, Figure A4), echoing earlier synchrony results ( Fig 4). The distance signature generally subsided after 1000â€“1500 km, pointing to the importance of one or several long-distance transmission events effectively acting as new sources and obscuring further distance effects.
